message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The tumor is of neuronal origin, and among the options, only Synaptophysin is a marker for neural tissue. Desmin is a muscle marker, Glial fibrillary acidic protein is specific to astrocytes, and Cytokeratin is found in epithelial cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and imaging findings suggest a brain tumor, and the fact that it is of neuronal origin suggests that it is a type of neuroblastoma. Among the options, Synaptophysin is a marker for neuroendocrine cells and is often used to diagnose neuroblastoma. Desmin and Cytokeratin are markers for muscle and epithelial cells, respectively, and Glial fibrillary acidic protein is a marker for astrocytes, which are not normally found in neuronal tumors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and imaging findings suggest a possible intraventricular tumor, and the fact that it is of neuronal origin suggests it is likely a neuroblastoma. Synaptophysin is a marker for neuroendocrine tumors like neuroblastoma. Desmin is a marker for muscle cells, glial fibrillary acidic protein is a marker for astrocytes, and cytokeratin is a marker for epithelial cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and location of the tumor suggest it could be a craniopharyngioma or a pineal gland tumor, both of which are of neuronal origin. Among the options, only Synaptophysin is a marker for neurons and would stain positive. Desmin, Glial fibrillary acidic protein, and Cytokeratin are markers for other cell types and would not be expected to stain positive in a neural tumor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the CT scan findings suggest a brain tumor, and the fact that it is of neuronal origin suggests that the cells will likely stain positive for Synaptophysin, which is a commonly used marker for neuronal tumors. Desmin is a marker for muscle cells, Glial fibrillary acidic protein is used to identify astrocytes (glial cells), and Cytokeratin is a marker for epithelial cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and location of the tumor suggest it is a brain tumor, and the fact that it is of neuronal origin narrows down the options to Synaptophysin and Glial fibrillary acidic protein. Synaptophysin is a marker for neuroendocrine cells, which are characteristic of neuronal tumors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a brain tumor, and the fact that the tumor is of neuronal origin suggests that it will stain positive for Synaptophysin, which is a marker for synaptic vesicles in neurons. Desmin is a marker for muscle and Glial fibrillary acidic protein is a marker for astrocytes. Cytokeratin is a marker for epithelial cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the location and appearance of the tumor suggest it is a brain tumor, likely of neuronal origin, and Synaptophysin is an immunohistochemical marker commonly used to identify neuronal cells. Desmin is used to identify muscle cells, Glial fibrillary acidic protein is used to identify astrocytes, and Cytokeratin is used to identify epithelial cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and imaging suggest that the tumor is likely a pineal gland tumor, which is most commonly a germinoma or pineoblastoma. These are neuroepithelial tumors that stain positive for Synaptophysin. Desmin is a marker for muscle, Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) is a marker for glial cells, and Cytokeratin is a marker for epithelial cells, none of which are found in neuronal tumors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The intraventricular location and neuronal origin suggest that the tumor is a central neurocytoma, which will stain positive for synaptophysin, a well-known neuronal marker. Desmin is a marker for muscle cells, glial fibrillary acidic protein is a marker for astrocytes, and cytokeratin is a marker for epithelial cells.
